The next ‘big things’ in display technology must be useful to a much larger demographic- on the order of 95% or so.4k is the most recognized new standard, but it isn't the newest, nor does it meet that larger demographic requirement. Fact is, some people can't see the difference in a program in native 1080p and 4k(2160p). It's about to become a moot point as the cost to manufacture 4k displays has dropped nearly to the point of manufacturing 1080p display. Soon, it'll be cheaper to only manufacture 4k screens and do away with the vast majority of 1080p models*.*We may see 1080p displays among the smaller sizes (I'd guess 32″ and down) as that level of detail isn't perceptible to most folks.So, what's next? There exists a small bit of content in 8k- so long as you have a set like the 88″ OLED TV that LG debuted at CES earlier this year. It's only $20,000- what a deal!Doubling down on the number of pixels every few years isn't it. What if we could make the picture better in another way?This is where HDR comes in. HDR- or high dynamic range- is the difference between the darkest black and the brightest white-basically meaning better colors. Ever notice how a red sports car doesn't *pop* on TV like it does in person? A display without HDR isn't capable of rendering some of those hues and shades. Today, there are 2 major standards in HD-Dolby Vision and HDR-10. Dolby Vision is objectively better, but to use it, manufacturers must pay Dolby royalties. HDR-10 is an open standard- meaning anyone can use it.To me, displays are sharp enough for now. The only reason to get more pixels is for a truly gigantic picture. 100 inches and up, 8k starts to make a lot more sense. Today, HDR is taking immersion to whole new levels, and what's better is that unlike pixels, HDR can be updated with software- you don't have to upgrade yet again.The next thing will likely be 360 degree video- what is erroneously called virtual reality today. But that's another answer.
